title: How honest are we?
intro: Are you honest? Have you ever cheated anybody? Rob and Neil discuss if honesty comes naturally to people or if it is a product of living in a social group.
this_week_question: Who said 'honesty is the best policy'? Was it…
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: trick or deceive someone to get something you want
person who buys things or services
the way the human mind works, the way we think
someone who only cares about themselves and not about other people

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English, where we bring you an interesting topic and six items of vocabulary. I'm Neil, and joining me is Rob.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Hello there! And today we've got six minutes to talk about honesty and how honest people are – particularly when it comes to spending money. So Neil – what's an 'honesty box'?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, it's where you pay for something by putting money in a box – but it's up to you to put in the right amount. A small business might use this method to take money for things like parking your car or buying a newspaper because it means you don't need a sales assistant.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: But that means people could take a newspaper or park their car without paying anything! An honesty box relies on people being honest. The adjective honest means truthful and not trying to cheat people.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And the noun is honesty – the quality of being truthful. Have you ever cheated an honesty box, Rob?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Absolutely not! I've never have!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Honestly?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Honestly! And to cheat , by the way, means to trick or deceive someone to get something you want. Honesty is the best policy, as they say…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Which of course leads us on to our quiz. Dan The 6 minute English quiz! Who said ‘honesty is the best policy’? Was it…

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Honestly, Neil! Everyone will know the answer to that.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But do you know the answer to that, Rob?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, I'll have an honest guess. I think it's b) Benjamin Franklin.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, you might be right, but you might not – we'll find out at the end. I did like your use of 'honestly' there, Rob. We can use the adverb 'honestly' at the beginning of a sentence to show that we're feeling irritated – for example when your co-presenter picks a quiz question that's too easy!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK, OK, let's move on now and hear from Philip Graves, a psychologist, and author of the book Consumerology , who can tell us about why honesty isn't always the best policy.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Philip Graves, Psychologist and author of the book Consumerology The question is not 'Are most consumers honest, the question is 'Are most people honest?' – And the answer to that is 'no'. We have evolved with the capacity to be dishonest. It's part of our evolutionary psychological make up – because if we can gain an advantage over the people around us, we have a greater chance of surviving. Now what's important in that is that we also benefited from being in a social group and that was important in our evolutionary past so there is a balance to strike between the extent to which we can feather our own nest, so to speak, and the risk of being ostracised by the group.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: A consumer is a person who buys things or services – for example, food or clothes.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Or the use of a parking space – or a taxi.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Now, if I park my car and don't pay for the parking space, I'm being dishonest, but I'm also saving money.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And Philip Graves says being dishonest is part of our 'psychological make up'. What does that mean?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Our psychological make up is the way the human mind works – the way we think.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And it makes sense to be dishonest if you gain an advantage through this behaviour. So when you take something without paying for it, you save money you can spend on something else.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So why do we place such importance on being honest then? – If we benefit from being dishonest?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Because it's selfish behaviour – which other members of our social group won't like. If everybody acted selfishly and dishonestly all the time, the world would be a very unpleasant place!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Selfish – meaning only caring about yourself and not about other people. That's a good point, Rob.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes, societies work better if people behave co-operatively – which means working together towards shared goals.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So honesty really is the best policy then – at least most of the time! Dan And now it's time for the answer to the quiz. Who said ‘honesty is the best policy’? Neil What do you think, Rob?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK. Was it Benjamin Franklin?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And that was… the right answer! Maybe the question was too easy! Benjamin Franklin wrote it in a book of proverbs called Poor Richard's Almanac between 1732 and 1758. Other famous quotes include 'There are no gains without pains' and 'Have you something to do tomorrow? Do it today.' OK let's follow Franklin's wise words and move right ahead with the vocabulary items we learned today.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: First up was the adjective honest – meaning truthful and not trying to cheat people – For example, 'Neil has a very honest face'. OK, then there's … um …. honesty and honestly… the noun and adverb forms. For example, erm…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Honestly, Rob, hurry up and do the second item!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK, OK, I'm getting there! To cheat – means to behave dishonestly to get what you want.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: My granny always used to cheat in card games. It was so annoying!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And I always used to cheat in spelling tests at school!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: How dishonest, Rob! OK, number three. Consumer – a person who buys goods or services for their own personal use.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: For example, 'I am a big consumer of chocolate bars'.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That's terrible English, Rob! How about – 'We asked UK consumers how much money they spent on food every month'?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK, I agree that's a better example. Anyway, I never consume chocolate. Number four!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Psychological make up – the way our minds work. The way we think.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: For example, 'He had the psychological make up of a serial killer…'

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That's nasty! Moving on – selfish – caring only about yourself and not other people.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: You only made yourself a cup of tea – that was a selfish thing to do!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: What???

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: It was just an example. You're not selfish, Neil. You're actually the most co-operative person I know – you're happy to work with others towards a common goal.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Not selfish then?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Never selfish. Always co-operative… And honest too.

transcript.author: Neil
